lab-1-step-1-ig1.prompt: A welcoming, futuristic graphic with the title 'Lab 1: Build Your First Portfolio Website' prominently displayed.

lab-1-step-2-ig1.prompt: A screenshot of the official Visual Studio Code download page.

lab-1-step-3-ig1.prompt: The user opens the Extensions view in VS Code. They click the '...' menu in the Extensions view sidebar. They select 'Install from VSIX...' from the dropdown menu. A file dialog opens, and the user selects the `data-curation-environment-0.1.10.vsix` file. A notification appears in the bottom-right indicating the extension is installing. Once complete, a notification confirms the installation, and the Data Curation icon appears in the Activity Bar.
lab-1-step-3-ig1.alt: Installing a VSIX in VS Code.

lab-1-step-4-ig1.prompt: The user opens Windows File Explorer and navigates to the `C:\` drive. They create a new folder and name it `Projects`. They navigate into the new `Projects` folder. They create a new folder inside `Projects` and name it `portfolio-website`.

lab-1-step-5-ig1.prompt: In VS Code, the user clicks the 'Open Folder' button from the 'File Tree View' panel. The file dialog opens, and the user navigates to and selects the `C:\Projects\portfolio-website` folder. VS Code reloads, opening the selected folder as the new workspace.
lab-1-step-5-ig1.alt: Opening the project folder in VS Code.

lab-1-step-6-ig1.prompt: The user clicks the spiral icon for the Data Curation Environment in the Activity Bar. The PCPP (Parallel Co-Pilot Panel) opens to the 'Welcome' / Onboarding screen. The user copies the provided project scope text. The user pastes the text into the large 'Project Scope' text area in the PCPP.

lab-1-step-8-ig1.prompt: In the PCPP Onboarding view, the user clicks the 'Generate Initial Artifacts Prompt' button. The view transitions to Cycle 1. Two new files, `DCE_README.md` and `prompt.md`, are automatically created and opened in the editor.

lab-1-step-12-ig1.prompt: The user opens a web browser. They navigate to `aistudio.google.com`. They configure the model settings: Model to `Gemini 2.5 Pro`, Temperature to `0.7`, and Thinking budget to maximum. The user duplicates the browser tab three times, creating a total of four identical AI Studio tabs.

lab-1-step-15-ig1.prompt: In the PCPP, the user pastes the four AI responses into the `Resp 1`, `Resp 2`, `Resp 3`, and `Resp 4` tabs. After the last response is pasted, the 'Parse All' button in the header becomes highlighted. The user clicks the 'Parse All' button. The UI for all tabs transforms into the parsed view, showing sections for Summary, Course of Action, and Associated Files.

lab-1-step-17-ig1.prompt: After parsing, the 'Sort' button is highlighted. The user clicks it. The tabs reorder based on their token count. The user ensures the first (longest) tab is active. The 'Select This Response' button in the response header is highlighted. The user clicks it. The selected response's tab turns green, indicating it has been chosen.

lab-1-step-18-ig1.prompt: After selecting a response, the 'Baseline (Commit)' button is highlighted. The user clicks the 'Baseline (Commit)' button. A VS Code error notification appears in the bottom-right corner with the message 'This is not a git repository.' and offers two buttons: 'Open README Guide' and 'Initialize Repository'.
lab-1-step-18-ig1.alt: The Git repository not found error.

lab-1-step-22-ig1.prompt: The 'Select All' button in the 'Associated Files' list is highlighted. The user clicks it, checking all files. The 'Accept Selected' button is highlighted. The user clicks it. The new artifact files appear in the VS Code File Explorer under `src/Artifacts`. The user clicks on the `GitHub-Repository-Setup-Guide.md` file to open and review its contents.

lab-1-step-26-ig1.prompt: The `+` (New Cycle) button in the Cycle Navigator is highlighted. The user clicks the `+` button. The view transitions to a new, empty 'Cycle 2'.

lab-1-step-27-ig1.prompt: The user is in the empty Cycle 2 view. They paste four new AI responses into the tabs. They click 'Parse All.' They click 'Sort.' They click 'Select This Response' on the longest response. They click 'Select All' in the 'Associated Files' list. They click 'Accept Selected.' The new `Git-Installation-Guide.md` file appears in the `src/Artifacts` directory.

lab-1-step-28-ig1.prompt: The user follows the instructions in the newly created `Git-Installation-Guide.md`. They navigate to the Git download website. They download and run the Git installer for Windows, accepting the default options. After installation, they open a new terminal in VS Code. They type `git --version` to verify the installation was successful.

lab-1-step-31-ig1.prompt: In the PCPP, the user navigates back to Cycle 1. They change the Cycle Title to 'First Commit.' They click the 'Baseline (Commit)' button, which brings up the 'not a git repository' error again. This time, they click the 'Initialize Repository' button on the error notification. A success message appears. They click the 'Baseline (Commit)' button one last time, and a 'Successfully created baseline commit' notification appears.

lab-1-step-32-ig1.prompt: The user creates a new cycle (Cycle 2). They set the Cycle Title to 'Create Project Scaffold' and the context to 'Let's now build the project files...'. They click 'Generate prompt.md.' They copy the content of the new `prompt.md`. They go to AI Studio and paste the prompt into the four tabs, generating four new responses. They create a new cycle (Cycle 3) in the PCPP. They paste the four new responses into the tabs for Cycle 3.

lab-1-step-34-ig1.prompt: In Cycle 3, the user clicks 'Parse All,' then 'Sort.' They select the longest response. They click 'Baseline (Commit),' which succeeds. The user clicks 'Select All' in the 'Associated Files' list. They click 'Accept Selected.' A large number of new project files appear in the VS Code File Explorer.
lab-1-step-34-ig1.alt: Baselining and accepting the scaffold code.

lab-1-step-36-ig1.prompt: A screenshot of the portfolio website running for the first time in a browser.

lab-1-step-37-ig1.prompt: The user opens Windows File Explorer. They create a new `context` folder in the `portfolio-website` directory. Inside `context`, they create a `personal` folder. They drag and drop their `My_Resume.pdf` file into the `personal` folder. Back in VS Code, they refresh the File Tree View to see the new folders and file. They check the box next to the `context` folder to add it to their selection.
lab-1-step-37-ig1.alt: Continuing to iterate by adding new context.
